item.title: Connected
When You're a Kid
item.description: When you’re a kid, everything is astonishing. Everything is new. And so your brain is awake and turned on. So every second, your brain is learning something new: how the world works. And so the muscle of your brain is activated. And as you get older and your brain has figured out the patterns of how the world works: this is how you make money; this is how you graduate school; this is how you get a mortgage; this is how you have kids… And once your brain establishes a routine, it stops.

item.title: What is a Floating World
item.description: “Living only for the moment, turning our attention to the pleasures of the moon, the snow, the cherry blossoms and the maples, singing songs, drinking wine and diverting ourselves in just floating, floating, caring not a whit for the poverty staring us in the face, refusing to be disheartened, like a gourd floating along with the river current: this is what we call the floating world.” From A Tale of the Floating World, by Asai Rydi, about 1665 (translated by Richard Lane)

item.title: Shi's Understanding of Procrastination
item.description: “The worst thing about procrastination is not to delay, but to make yourself hesitant or even lose confidence.” “Whatever you do, decide, and do it right away, which in itself makes people lively and maintains a sense of initiative and happiness.”

item.title: Oscar
item.description: “Political correctness” was quietly discussed at the time of the victory of “Everything Everywhere All at Once”. This view arose early when Moonlight Boy won the award that year; after all, it was another hard look at the rise of minorities. Some people say that “political correctness” is the biggest source of antipathy for hypocrisy - a polite and friendly way to give way to smiling may follow the social identity of “good citizens,” as to the extent to which this act of kindness is due to “you” is hard to know.
